urn:contentItem:5SJJ-J2X1-JCJY-G3H4-00000-00Comcast's offer starts bidding war;$65bn on table for 21st Century Fox assets2018-06-14T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:35:22ZLexisNexisBUSINESSVersion:2Comcast's offer starts bidding war$65bn on table for 21st Century Fox assetsJames Dean, US Business Editor

Comcast kicked off a bidding war for 21st Century Fox's prized entertainment and distribution assets last night with an offer nearly $13 billion higher than Walt Disney's.

The $65 billion all-cash bid by Comcast was larger than expected and almost certainly will force Disney to raise its $52.4 billion all-shares offer or walk away from the deal.

Disney, the $160 billion film, television and theme parks conglomerate, and Comcast, a $147 billion cable television giant, are vying for a package of assets from 21st Century Fox that includes the Twentieth Century Fox film studio and its stake in Sky, the British satellite broadcaster. The remainder of 21st Century Fox, which will concentrate on news and sports, will be spun off into another company dubbed New Fox.

The trigger for Comcast's bid was AT&T's resounding court victory over the Department of Justice on Tuesday night, when a federal judge ruled that the telecoms company's blockbuster merger with Time Warner, the television and film company, could go ahead. Comcast believes that AT&T's win will make it easier to get its deal with 21st Century Fox past the department's competition enforcers.

Traditional media companies are turning to mergers as they try to make up ground on the fast-growing video streaming services, such as Netflix and Amazon Prime Video, and digital advertisers, such as Google and Facebook. AT&T's victory is likely to be a precursor to a spate of deals in the industry.

21st Century Fox, which is valued at nearly $80 billion, is an American media company. Rupert Murdoch, chairman of News Corp, owner of The Times, is co-chairman of 21st Century Fox with his son Lachlan. His other son, James, is chief executive of 21st Century Fox and chairman of Sky.

In a letter to the three executives, Brian Roberts, chief executive of Comcast, said that his company had "long admired what the Murdoch family has built" at 21st Century Fox and was "convinced" that the businesses it was selling to Disney would find the "right strategic home" at Comcast.

Mr Roberts said the company was "disappointed" when 21st Century Fox decided to sell to Disney last year when Comcast had offered more. 21st Century Fox pointed to concerns that regulators could scupper such a deal.

Comcast has offered to pay a $2.5 billion termination fee to 21st Century Fox if the deal is blocked, the same offered by Disney. Comcast also said that it would pay the $1.5 billion fee that 21st Century Fox would owe to Disney if it walks away from their deal.

21st Century Fox said last night that it would "carefully review and consider the Comcast proposal".

Shares in 21st Century Fox closed up 7.7 per cent at a record high of $43.66 in New York last night, with Disney shares rising by 1.9 per cent to $106.31 and those of Comcast shares closing down by 0.2 per cent at $32.32.

Ruling paves way for flurry of mega deals Wall Street's dealmakers had waited with bated breath for Tuesday's night's judgment in the court battle between AT&T and the Department of Justice, so when Judge Richard Leon ruled decisively against the government, after a six-week trial, the champagne corks began popping (James Dean writes).

The ruling has paved the way for a flurry of monster deals to proceed in the media, telecoms and healthcare industries, and for new ones to be brokered. Nearly all have the same thing in common: they are do-or-die attempts to counter the power of Big Tech.

AT&T's core business is content distribution and Time Warner's is content creation. The companies argue that a merger is necessary to help them to challenge Netflix, the $161 billion video streaming company that recently surpassed Walt Disney to become the world's most valuable entertainment business.

The same argument is proffered by Disney and Comcast as they vie for 21st Century Fox's entertainment assets. Traditional media companies are also being squeezed for advertising revenue by Google and Facebook, which dominate the digital world.

The AT&T and Time Warner tie-up is a "vertical" merger, in that two distinct companies combine without removing a competitor from the market. A proposed marriage of CVS, the $70 billion pharmacy chain, and Aetna, the $62 billion health insurer, also fits this category and is now less likely to be challenged by the DoJ's competition division. Their companies' shares were up by 2.4 per cent and 3.6 per cent, respectively, yesterday morning.

Cigna, another health insurer, is seeking to buy Express Scripts, a pharmacy benefits manager, for $67 billion. Their shares were respectively down by 1.3 per cent and up by 3.8 per cent.

Amazon, the $825 billion ecommerce giant, hinted last year that it could start delivering pharmaceuticals by post, which is big business in the United States. In February Amazon said it was setting up a healthcare company to cut employee medical costs. Many believe that this is a precursor to a broader push into healthcare.

T-Mobile US's proposed $26 billion acquisition of Sprint is more likely to face scrutiny as it is a "horizontal" merger of competitors. T-Mobile US, valued at $48 billion, is the No 3 network and Sprint the No 4. It is the third time in four years that they have tried to merge. Their shares were up by 1.4 per cent yesterday.

urn:contentItem:5FV5-MHY1-JCHV-V270-00000-00Comcast, Time Warner Cable Stock Still Attractive Even Without Merger2015-04-24T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:35:22ZLexisNexisComcast, Time Warner CableStock Still Attractive Even Without MergerJeff Berman

However, the scuttled merger could be a slight negative for each company, according to one analyst.

NEW YORK ( TheStreet ) -- Wall Street still likes Comcast and Time Warner Cable  despite the media companies    calling off their planned marriage .

Comcast pulled the proposed $45 billion merger on Friday after the Federal Communications Commission recommended an administrative hearing for the deal, an almost certain slow death for the transaction .


But shares of Comcast and Time Warner Cablewere rising Friday, a testament to the   overall strength  of their position in a media industry in need of high-speed Internet connections. Comcast was up nearly 1% to $59.70 while Time Warner Cablejumped 3.5% to $154.


Must Read:10 New Stocks Billionaire David Einhorn Loves

"Fundamentals remain strong," Macquarie Securities analyst Amy Yong said by email, referring to Comcast and Time Warner Cable.


Comcast, Yong said, is now free to pursue additional acquisitions or efforts to return capital to investors in the form of share buybacks, as well as expand its overseas holdings or add content companies to NBCUniversal. Comcast could also spend its cash acquiring spectrum to bolster its wireless business, she said.

Regardless of the merger, Comcast remains a compelling investment, said Buckingham Research Group analyst James Ratcliffe. 


"We expect continued strong operating performance from the company and accelerating capital returns," Ratcliffe said of Comcast in a note to investors.

Time Warner Cablestands to gain from a likely merger offer  from Charter Communications , the broadband provider controlled by billionaire John Malone.

Time Warner Cable's stock is supported, in part, by an expected $2.7 billion stock buyback authorization, Yong said in a research note. Over the past year, Time Warner Cable  management improved operations with initiatives such as its Maxx Internet and TV service, she said.

Charter will likely offer Time Warner Cablea bid somewhere between $150 to $160, up from its offer more than a year ago to buy the country's second-largest cable-TV provider for $132.50 a share, Yong said said. Assuming a 60% cash and 40% stock deal at $150 to $160 a share, she projects a merged Charter and Time Warner Cablewould be worth around $220 per share.


To be sure, the dropped bid could become a slight negative for each cable company, said Pacific Crest Securities analyst Andy Hargreaves in a research note just before Comcast's announcement that it was terminating the merger. "Increased regulatory scrutiny could prompt cable companies to raise broadband prices less aggressively in the future for fear of drawing even more attention," he said.


But Comcast retains solid growth prospects based on the size of its broadband network and the possibility that it will introduce its own standalone video service to compete with Netflix and Time Warner's HBO NOW.


Time Warner Cablewould similarly trade at a lower value than previously expected, he said, estimating a 12-month fair value of $134 a share. A new merger deal with Charter remains likely, although Hargreaves said there's no reason for Charter to pay a premium to the current market price of $149.

urn:contentItem:5XKK-01S1-JCMN-Y3DX-00000-00Comedian Sacha Baron Cohen Condemns Facebook for Free Speech Stance2019-11-26T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:35:22ZLexisNexisComedian Sacha Baron Cohen Condemns Facebook for Free Speech StanceAlexander Hall

Nov 25, 2019( Newsbusters.org: http://newsbusters.org/ Delivered by Newstex) An actor and comedian famous for his shenanigans as the character Borat blasted the Big Tech community for being 'the greatest propaganda machine in history' and knocking Facebook for its recent free speech stance.Sacha Baron Cohen gave a speech[1] at the Anti-Defamation League's 2019 Never Is Now Summit on Anti-Semitism and Hate last Thursday, claiming that 'hate and violence is being facilitated by a handful of internet companies that amount to the greatest propaganda machine in history.''Cohen is best known for portraying the fictional characters Borat, Ali G, and Bruno. Each of them indulges a similar shtick: Tricking famous people into outrageous interviews in order to humiliate them,' suggested Reason Magazine[2].But it is not just the powerful. Cohen allegedly tricked an economically-troubled village in Romania, allegedly telling them they were being filmed in a documentary, when they were used as a comical fake village from which Cohen's 'Borat' character came.

'[T]he villagers of Glod in Romania, which doubled as Borat's village in Kazakhstan, went to the courts, unsuccessfully demanding $38m for being depicted as inbreeds, rapists, thieves and prostitutes,' The Telegraph[3] reported.Specifically naming "Facebook, YouTube and Google, Twitter and others," Cohen declared in his Thursday speech that he believed 'it's time for a fundamental rethink of social media and how it spreads hate, conspiracies, and lies."He condemned Zuckerberg's recent speech[4] about the importance of free expression at Georgetown University, calling some of Zuckerberg's arguments, 'pardon my French, bullshit.''This is not about limiting anyone's free speech. This is about giving people, including some of the most reprehensible people on earth, the biggest platform in history to reach a third of the planet. Freedom of speech is not freedom of reach.'Cohen also quoted the First Amendment, that ''Congress shall make no law' abridging freedom of speech,' ignoring regulations already placed on internet communication and seemingly advocating for online censorship of ideals that with which he and those on the left disagree.Cohen blasted Zuckerberg's commitment to keeping Facebook as an open platform, and asked, 'If a neo-Nazi comes goose-stepping into a restaurant and starts threatening other customers and saying he wantsto kill Jews, would the owner of the restaurant, a private business, be required to serve him an elegant eight-course meal?'But as reported on before, who determines who or what counts as a Nazi? If you listen to some[5] in the mainstream liberal media, then that answer might just be President Donald Trump.He suggested Zuckerberg 'seemed to equate regulation of companies like his to the actions of 'the most repressive societies'' and was incredulous at the comparison.He condemned Big Tech CEOs as people who care 'more about boosting their share price than about protecting democracy.' He dubbed this alleged phenomenon as 'ideological imperialism' and lamented how 'six unelected individuals in Silicon Valley [are] imposing their vision on the rest of the world, unaccountable to any government and acting like they're above the reach of law.'Finally, Cohen blasted Zuckerberg for 'welcoming a 'diversity of ideas,'' suggesting that our elected officials should have a say in what goes online and further suggesting that 'groups like the ADL' should monitor social media to fact-check and purge lies and conspiracies from online platforms.Then Cohen himself gave an example of why his solution, in fact, presents a problem. 'On the internet, everything can appear equally legitimate' he complained later, citing how 'Breitbart resembles the BBC.' But which outlet is to be believed? Seemingly, Cohen prefers one and not the other. And this comparison comes after a recent decision by Facebook to include Breitbart in its human- curated 'News' tab[6] in an effort to represent all sides of political debate, provided they adhere to the platform's terms of service. urn:contentItem:5XKJ-XN01-DXKX-01FM-00000-00Comedian Sacha Baron Cohen Condemns Facebook for Free Speech Stance2019-11-26T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:35:22ZLexisNexisComedian Sacha Baron Cohen Condemns Facebook for Free Speech Stance

Nov 25, 2019( Newsbusters.org: http://newsbusters.org/Delivered by Newstex) An actor and comedian famous for his shenanigans as the character Borat blasted the Big Tech community for being 'the greatest propaganda machine in history' and knocking Facebook for its recent free speech stance.Sacha Baron Cohen gave a speech[1] at the Anti-Defamation League's 2019 Never Is Now Summit on Anti-Semitism and Hate last Thursday, claiming that 'hate and violence is being facilitated by a handful of internet companies that amount to the greatest propaganda machine in history.''Cohen is best known for portraying the fictional characters Borat, Ali G, and Bruno. Each of them indulges a similar shtick: Tricking famous people into outrageous interviews in order to humiliate them,' suggested Reason Magazine[2].But it is not just the powerful. Cohen allegedly tricked an economically-troubled village in Romania, allegedly telling them they were being filmed in a documentary, when they were used as a comical fake village from which Cohen's 'Borat' character came.

'[T]he villagers of Glod in Romania, which doubled as Borat's village in Kazakhstan, went to the courts, unsuccessfully demanding $38m for being depicted as inbreeds, rapists, thieves and prostitutes,' The Telegraph[3] reported.Specifically naming "Facebook, YouTube and Google, Twitter and others," Cohen declared in his Thursday speech that he believed 'it's time for a fundamental rethink of social media and how it spreads hate, conspiracies, and lies."He condemned Zuckerberg's recent speech[4] about the importance of free expression at Georgetown University, calling some of Zuckerberg's arguments, 'pardon my French, bullshit.''This is not about limiting anyone's free speech. This is about giving people, including some of the most reprehensible people on earth, the biggest platform in history to reach a third of the planet. Freedom of speech is not freedom of reach.'Cohen also quoted the First Amendment, that ''Congress shall make no law' abridging freedom of speech,' ignoring regulations already placed on internet communication and seemingly advocating for online censorship of ideals that with which he and those on the left disagree.Cohen blasted Zuckerberg's commitment to keeping Facebook as an open platform, and asked, 'If a neo-Nazi comes goose-stepping into a restaurant and starts threatening other customers and saying he wantsto kill Jews, would the owner of the restaurant, a private business, be required to serve him an elegant eight-course meal?'But as reported on before, who determines who or what counts as a Nazi? If you listen to some[5] in the mainstream liberal media, then that answer might just be President Donald Trump.He suggested Zuckerberg 'seemed to equate regulation of companies like his to the actions of 'the most repressive societies'' and was incredulous at the comparison.He condemned Big Tech CEOs as people who care 'more about boosting their share price than about protecting democracy.' He dubbed this alleged phenomenon as 'ideological imperialism' and lamented how 'six unelected individuals in Silicon Valley [are] imposing their vision on the rest of the world, unaccountable to any government and acting like they're above the reach of law.'Finally, Cohen blasted Zuckerberg for 'welcoming a 'diversity of ideas,'' suggesting that our elected officials should have a say in what goes online and further suggesting that 'groups like the ADL' should monitor social media to fact-check and purge lies and conspiracies from online platforms.Then Cohen himself gave an example of why his solution, in fact, presents a problem. 'On the internet, everything can appear equally legitimate' he complained later, citing how 'Breitbart resembles the BBC.' But which outlet is to be believed? Seemingly, Cohen prefers one and not the other. And this comparison comes after a recent decision by Facebook to include Breitbart in its human- curated 'News' tab[6] in an effort to represent all sides of political debate, provided they adhere to the platform's terms of service. urn:contentItem:5WPW-48N1-JB20-G02H-00000-00Comey Gets A Pass Escaping Prosecution; Standing Up To China; Trump In Cincinnati; DOJ Won't Prosecute Comey For Leaks Despite Watchdog Criminal Referral; President Trump To Impose Tariffs On Additional $300 Billion Worth Of Chinese Goods; Trump Arrives At Ohio Rally; North Korea Launches Two Missiles, A Third Weapons Test In Eight Days; United States Working To Withdraw Troops From Afghanistan In Deal With Taliban; Assault On U.S. Workers; Senator Hawley: Green Card Giveaway Bill Yet To Be Discussed by Judiciary Committee; 2020 Dems Attack Each Other; Dems Attack Joe Biden During Last Night's Debate; Catch And Release; Revamping Policy; ICE Releases Over 218K Illegal Family Members Since December 2018; President Donald Trump Rallies Supporters In Cincinnati, Ohio2019-08-01T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:35:22ZLexisNexisLOU DOBBS TONIGHT7:00 PM ESTNEWSFinancial080101cb.229Comey Gets A Pass Escaping Prosecution; Standing Up To China; Trump In Cincinnati; DOJ Won't Prosecute Comey For Leaks Despite Watchdog Criminal Referral; President Trump To Impose Tariffs On Additional $300 Billion Worth Of Chinese Goods; Trump Arrives At Ohio Rally; North Korea Launches Two Missiles, A Third Weapons Test In Eight Days; United States Working To Withdraw Troops From Afghanistan In Deal With Taliban; Assault On U.S. Workers; Senator Hawley: Green Card Giveaway Bill Yet To Be Discussed by Judiciary Committee; 2020 Dems Attack Each Other; Dems Attack Joe Biden During Last Night's Debate; Catch And Release; Revamping Policy; ICE Releases Over 218K Illegal Family Members Since December 2018; President Donald Trump Rallies Supporters In Cincinnati, OhioLou Dobbs, Thomas Homan, Todd Starnes, Byron York, Ed Rollins, Tammy Bruce

LOU DOBBS, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Good evening, everybody. Good evening. Deep state strikes again, disgraced former James Comey, apparently will escape prosecution. The Justice Department Inspector General referred Comey for potential prosecution for leaking classified information. We take up the latest developments in that issue here tonight.

President Trump continues to defend the United States against years of theft of trillions of American dollars, theft of American technology and intellectual property, and unfair trade, of course, by the Chinese. The president announcing additional tariffs to be levied on Chinese goods, those tariffs will be imposed beginning September 1st if the United States and the People's Republic of China fail to reach a trade deal by that date.

And the president just two hours ago acknowledged he is considering a blockade of Venezuela. You're looking now at pictures -- live pictures of Cincinnati, Ohio, where the president is only moments away from addressing his ardent supporters in Cincinnati, but we'll -- we'll expect the president to address amongst other things the Chinese failure to honor their agreements, the necessity of tariffs.

He will surely be scoring last night's Debate of 2020 Democratic presidential hopefuls, and as always tickets to his rallies in high demand, only 18,000 seats available in this arena and the president telling me earlier today that more than 100,000 people had asked for tickets to this even tonight.

We'll bring you his remarks throughout this hour, as he expands on his administration's policy initiatives and news developments of the day. And yes, we suspect he may also take up a few political issues as well.

Breaking news tonight, according to Fox News sources, the Justice Department has decided not to prosecute former FBI Director James Comey for leaking classified information. This despite DOJ Inspector General Michael Horowitz who reported recommended a criminal referral for Comey.

The Hill's John Solomon reporting and writing that prosecutors found the IG's findings compelling, but they decided not bring charges because they apparently didn't believe they had enough evidence of Comey's intent to violate the law.

And President Trump today announced additional tariffs against China. Those tariffs will effective September 1st. President Trump threatened to impose 10 percent tariffs on the remaining $300 billion of Chinese goods exported into this country each year. These tariffs do not include the $250 billion of goods already under tariff at 25 percent. Radical Dem (ph) Senator Chuck Schumer, praising the president earlier today and aligning himself with the president on China. Listen to this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SEN. CHARLES SCHUMER, (D-NY): We have to be really tough on China. They've taken advantage of us. America has lost trillions of dollars and millions of jobs because China has not played fair. And being tough on China is the right way to be.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

DOBBS: And joining us live Byron, you are Chief Political Correspondent for the Washington Examiner, Fox Business Contributor. Byron, good to see you and did hear Chuck Schumer lineup with the president on any issue, is extraordinary and newsworthy, but on issue of trade with China it is important -- an important alliance.

BYRON YORK, CHIEF POLITICAL CORRESPONDENT, WASHINGTON EXAMINER: Schumer has done this before and you're absolutely right. This is a really big deal on anything, any president, it's not a bad idea to have leader of the opposition in Senate on your side, it -- It bodes well.

But specifically on China where Trump apparently has the support -- he has the support of the farmers in the Midwest who are hurting by this, but they're saying we have been abused by China for so long, something has to be done.

And really when you look at the complexity of this issue, when you look at practices of China over many, many years, this was not going to be easy.

And so, that -- that the fact that it is moving on this stage, and there have been fits and starts, and unkept promises, all of that stuff I think it was completely to be expected, but Schumer thing very good for president who can claim bipartisan as he does this.

DOBBS: He can claim it, and in fact, it is very important in his negotiations with Xi Jinping because of -- lied (ph) with the Democratic Party and its leadership, the Chinese have to understand.

There will be -- there will be but one result and that will be the president's position, and he won't be second guessed or undercut by many of the very same opponents within the Democratic Party who had undercut him for the first two and a half years of his presidency.

YORK: That's -- that's a very important point you raised which is that the president and American negotiators can say to the Chinese, "Look, this is not the president of United States out there all by his lonesome. The Democrats are on his side. The leader of the Senate Democrats is on his side with this."

So, if you're thinking about waiting Donald Trump out and it's all going to get better, you can go back to what you were doing before, not going to happen. You need to make a deal now.

DOBBS: And it comes as the president was, if you will, preparing the battleground, saying to the Chinese, that if you're going to wait (ph) me up, wait (ph) me up but I'm going to win 2020, and I'll be here waiting for you, and the deal will only get tougher and tougher.

So, the leverage is improving considerably. The president has plenty of it begin with, but now this is a marked improvement of the -- of the prospects.

I want to take up the -- the -- the issue of this rally tonight where the president is going to be, as he always does, talking policy, the initiatives that he is driving, and yes, the politics, of course, as well.

But now with so much going on whether it'd be Federal Reserve, the drive to cut interest rates, to deal with the -- the alliance that is, well, enlarging between Russia and China, and all that the president is contending within foreign policy, these are -- this is now the 2020 election writ large in a matter of just weeks.

YORK: Well, you know, Lou, you just listed a lot of really big and serious issues, but you know that a lot of the press coverage tonight about this, will be whether the crowd says, "Send her back again," that is whether the -- the chant that we heard briefly --

DOBBS: Right.

YORK: -- at this rally in the North Carolina will appear, again, the president says, he does not want that to happen.

DOBBS: Right.

YORK: You know, there's another thing that's really just sitting in plain sight with this, which is the president is drawing really big crowds. As you -- you mentioned, this is an 18,000 --

DOBBS: Yeah.

YORK: -- seat arena. If -- if -- if Kamala Harris or -- or Joe Biden or Bernie Sanders were pulling crowds like this at this stage in a race, that would be a very, very big story, and this is, of course -- it was the biggest single indicator of the intensity of Donald Trump support throughout the 2015 and 2016 as the -- as the campaign went on.

DOBBS: Yeah.

YORK: And he appears to be just going out and doing the same thing, getting enormous crowds, again.

DOBBS: All right. Having the opportunity to talk with the president earlier today by -- by phone as I indicated, he's -- he -- he was very proud of the fact that so many people wanted those tickets and by my count that's about a 5 to 1 ratio which, you know, I mean, you've - you need a guitar really to make those kind of claims.

This president has done so from almost the very moment. He began his candidacy back in 2015. It is truly a phenomenon.

YORK: It's a very big deal to him, too. I mean, obviously when he was in television, the ratings were a very big thing, crowd size is -- is really, really important to him, and it's -- it has been a marker of his popularity, and, you know, it -- and it's a marker of everybody else's as well.

I was in South Carolina a few weeks ago, went to a Kamala Harris' rally. It was in the middle of day in Myrtle Beach. She got a thousand people there which is pretty good.

DOBBS: Yeah, not bad.

YORK: Lunchtime, people had other stuff to do, but they came to the Kamala Harris' rally, so a thousand, very good, but you're talking multiples of that coming to Trump rallies.

DOBBS: Trump rally and, as you say, multiples and we're going to be going to -- to the rally as soon as the president takes the stage. And Byron, if you will, can you stay with us to -- to take -- to take part in the festivities as we try to watch what is happening politically to this president and -- and the issues that he is going to take up.

Always good to have you with us and thanks for -- for being here.

YORK: Thank you, Lou.

DOBBS: One of the things, we will certainly be taking up is the president's scoring of the debate last night. All of those Democratic hopefuls and their sudden attack on a president and it wasn't Donald Trump.

And we got more breaking news for you tonight North Korea has fired two more short range ballistic missiles into sea of Japan. It is the third weapons test in just over a week, the sixth since last year's summit with the president.

The North Koreans also firing short range ballistic missiles last Thursday. They tested a rocket launch on Wednesday. President Trump says, "The situation with North Korea, very much under control."

Up next, the radical Dems use the -- the latest debate to attack one of their own and, of course, each other and boy, did they ever. Also tonight, thousands gathering for the President's rally and well, actually tens of thousands in Cincinnati, Ohio. Look at that crowd. We'll be looking at that crowd and the president, here next right after these quick messages. Stay with us.

DOBBS: Breaking news now, the United States preparing to withdraw thousands of our troops from Afghanistan in a deal with the Taliban. The United States would slash the number of troops from 14,000 to about 9,000 in exchange for concessions from the Taliban, which would include a ceasefire, a renunciation of Al Qaeda.

The Taliban would also be forced to negotiate a peace deal with Afghan government and, of course, this withdrawal is absolutely conditional on reaching that agreement with the Taliban.

We've been reporting to you that American workers in the middle class are under assault in the Senate right now. Major business lobbyists, the biggest in the country, and they are the biggest lobbyists of any kind in the country, the Koch brothers, the business roundtable, Chamber of Commerce and yes, combined with the Republican and Democratic leadership, they intend to make it easier to outsource American jobs to cheap foreign labor.

Absolutely, really (ph) a contravention of the president his policies and everything he has run on. Senate Bill 386, it's called, it would mean the doubling of H-1B visas and that India and China would take most of those visas to compete directly with our American workers.

But a handful of Republican senators are skeptical at least some will oppose it amongst those who are skeptical and we will soon learn whether they will oppose the legislation.

Senator Josh Hawley, he told Fox News Bret Baier, that the bill has yet to be discussed in committee and that he, at least has serious concerns about what it would do to America's workers.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BRET BAIER, FOX NEWS ANCHOR: There is a bill -- Senate Bill 386, the Fairness for High-Skilled Immigrants Act, there were reports that it may be taken up and discussed in judiciary, has it been?

SEN. JOSH HAWLEY, (R-MO): It has not been and if -- if it comes before judiciary, I'll certainly look at this closely.

BAIER: Some see this as a gift to big tech (ph), and like Indian H-1B visa workers.

HAWLEY: Yeah, I would be concerned about anything that is a gift to big tech (ph) and anything that would hurt American workers or drive down wages. I mean, one of the features of our broken immigration system is that it has helped keep wages flat in this country for too long, especially for workers, who are trying the hardest to get a raise.

We have got to reform legal immigration so that our workers kind of have a chance to move forward.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

DOBBS: Senator Josh Hawley, well, this gift to our biggest lobbyist and this attack on our middle class is sponsored by Senator Mike Lee, cosponsored by 19 other rhinos (ph). They include Mitt Romney, Rob Portman, Joni Ernst, all of them willing to sell out apparently American working men and women and their families.

There are two telling lines today from the left wing national media. Those lines suggest that recent debates didn't go too well for the radical Dems 2020 hopefuls. Take a look at this, one headline from today's "Washington Post" reads this quote, "Facing Trump, Democrats turn on another president, Obama."

And the Washington Post, Dan Balz also writing in part, quote, "The candidates have done as much as -- as much to make a case against one another as against the president without offering much in the way of an aspirational message or connecting directly with the voters they will need to win the presidential election."

Joining me now, former Reagan White House political director, Fox Business political analyst and Republican strategist, Ed Rollins. Ed, good to have you here.

ED ROLLINS, GREAT AMERICA PAC CHAIRMAN: Thank you.

DOBBS: The Democrats having a tough night of it.

ROLLINS: Well, they're going to have tough time because, obviously, though -- the processes with 20 candidates in there and several other elected officials, some are articulate about their positions and some like Bernie Sanders and Elizabeth Warren who aren't (ph) in that debate last night or the night before, really are very passionate about their socialist beliefs.

And they basically -- the establishment is sort of the -- the Biden camp, and I don't think and no one else I think, thinks Biden can survive, but he -- he certainly doing or being canned up --

DOBBS: Or whether they can or he can't he has a huge lead in every major poll.

ROLLINS: He has in any -- in a -- at a low bar last night to pass it, and I would say that he passed it. But the reality is he's only claiming (ph) the fame at this point in time as he was a duck and dodges 40-year record is -- I was -- I was chosen by Obama.

So, therefore, the idea the -- I got to be vice president and Obama vetted me with 10 lawyers is a good excuse why the Democrats should nominate him.

DOBBS: I would (ph) --

ROLLINS: Go ahead.

DOBBS: -- let's give our audience a sample of -- if by any chance you missed the extraordinary evening over on CNN. Biden was attacked by a lot of folks on the stage. I think nearly every one of them.

Let's take a sample (ph).

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SEN. KAMALA HARRIS, (D-CA): In 2019, in America, for a Democrat to be running for president with a plan that does not cover everyone, I think is without excuse.

MAYOR BILL DE BLASIO, NEW YORK CITY, Mr. Vice President, you want to be president of United States, you need to be able to answer the tough questions, I guarantee if you're debating Donald Trump, he's not going to let you off the hook.

SEN. CORY BOOKER, (D-NJ): There are people right now, in prison for life for drug offenses, because you stood up and used that tough on crime phony rhetoric --

(END VIDEO CLIP)

DOBBS: And the -- and the parade went on, Ed.

ROLLINS: Well, it was -- this is much disarray in Democratic Party that I've seen since probably the -- when the -- when McGovern was the -- was the nominee back in `72.

You know, the reality here is they've got a long ways to go before they pick a nominee, and they have a different process than Republicans have -- Republicans have mostly winner take all primaries. They don't. You have to get 15 percent of the vote in order to get delegates.

So, you could draw this thing out for a period of time. It may narrow to five or six people, but those five or six people could fight all the way to the convention.

DOBBS: Right.

ROLLINS: And they're obviously on different -- different wavelengths than the vast majority of Americans.

DOBBS: This president has nearly everything going his way

ROLLINS: Absolutely.

DOBBS: The last several weeks - I mean, it's victory, after victory whether it's in a court, whether -- you name it on every -- every contested field, he is prevailing.

And then he has the Senate and Senate Bill 386, Mike Lee, 20 other rhinos (ph) that I mentioned going after American jobs and offering up more outsourcing to cheap foreign labor, it's outrageous what they're doing to the president.

His -- his motto, "Buy American, hire American," and he is standing up for the forgotten man and women in this country, and they are attacking him.

ROLLINS: Well not only that. It totally distracts him. The issue here is the border security and trying to fix that before anything else. They want to basically fix this with a Chamber of Commerce and like Koch brothers and the --

DOBBS: They're -- they're sold-out to the people who won (ph) --

ROLLINS: -- and that -- there's no -- there's no question and it's the -- it's the Washington (ph) lobbyists and that's what have you and the reality here is if this bill passes which obviously with this all -- his cosponsors that Republican vote (ph) with the Democrats, it will match (ph) --

DOBBS: Well, Mitch McConnell, you know, the -- all this nonsense about him being an agent of Russia. He is an agent though. It turns out he's an agent of Walls Street, the Koch brothers, the Chamber of Commerce. This is outrageous, and he should be supporting the president in stopping this before it is an embarrassment to him, his party and the president.

ROLLINS: I totally agree and that -- and then all the controversy around the tech community, I mean, this is something that shouldn't happen quickly.

DOBBS: Unbelievable.

ROLLINS: We really ought to make this thing drawn out and -- and if they pass it, the president needs to veto it with -- as I said the other night and he ought to make that clear right or today.

DOBBS: Ed Rollins, thanks so much, appreciate it.

ROLLINS: Thank you.

DOBBS: Up next, President Trump says, he's seen success along Southern Border.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: Getting very good numbers from the border. The 21,000 soldiers supplied by Mexico, and I want to thank, Mexico. They're doing a great job. The numbers are way down at the border.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

DOBBS: And we take up that progress with former acting ICE Director Tom Homan. We'll have the latest from President Trump's rally in Cincinnati. Stay with us, a lot more straight ahead and there is Vice President Mike Pence, and my guess is he's just about to introduce the president.

We'll have just a few quick commercial messages, and we'll be right back with the President of the United States. Stay with us.

DOBBS: Breaking news tonight, Immigration and Customs Enforcement has reported the release -- River Harden Lee (ph) released more than 218,000 illegal immigrant families into United States since the end of last year.

Homeland Security source telling the Washington Examiner's Anna Giaritelli, that the greatest number of illegal family members were released in Texas; 82,000 of them in San Antonio Region, 75,000 in El Paso Region.

Acting director of U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services, Ken Cuccinelli says, "Trump administration officials are clamping down on the oft ignored requirement that asylum seekers must first seek safety in their home country."

Cuccinelli reiterating that the requirement is not a new policy. It is the latest in the administration's effort to follow the law, to enforce the law, to secure the border and the lawsuits and judicial activism undercutting the president's border seeker are the efforts notwithstanding that's the pursuit -- the way they're going to proceed.

Joining me now, Tom Homan, former acting Director of Immigration and Customs Enforcement, also Fox Business contributor. Tom, great to have you with us. How should we interpret this? The ICE let 218,000 immigrant families loose in the country?

THOMAS HOMAN, FORMER ACTING DIRECTOR, IMMIGRATION AND CUSTOMS ENFORCEMENT: Well, there are a couple of ways you can interpret. First of all, they had to release them because the Flores Settlement Agreement, they can't hold them more than 20 days since they're trying up (ph) to see a judge.

DOBBS: Right.

HOMAN: And Congress has never funded ICE enough family detention beds. So, again, Congress failed to close that loopholes on Flores Settlement Agreement. Congress has failed to give ICE enough money to have more family detention beds.

But the second part of this, ICE needs to go out there and find, look family (ph) units have final orders in a large scale operation and remove that. I've been saying this and you know, I've been talking about this --

DOBBS: Yes.

HOMAN: -- for a year now. And that -- it needs to happen because until you show a consequence - until you show determination (ph) -- if a judge orders you remove, you're going to go home and we're going to make sure you go home and Central America needs to see those planes coming home.

DOBBS: You know, the president talked about Interior (ph) Enforcement, you've been talking about it. I -- Mark Morgan, the acting head of Border Protection Customs and Border Protection. It just isn't happening. What's the reason it's not happening? Because as you mentioned Congress, you and I and everyone watching this broadcast knows that this Democratic Congress isn't going to lift a finger to help Donald Trump secure the border and enforce immigration law. So they've got to do it on their own.

HOMAN: Yes, and you and I have talked about it many times, the courts aren't helping them except very rarely.

DOBBS: Right.

HOMAN: And certainly Congress doesn't want to help them, so we need to do everything we can within the -- within the boundaries of the law. Ken Cuccinelli is doing exactly that, we just open this segment with. He's going back and he's going to force all the laws he can within CIS. And that's the same thing the Border Patrol needs to do and ICE needs to do. ICE needs to gather national operation. I know ICE is hurting for resources because you're dealing with the crisis on the border. But you know what, they got 218,000 special agents and I saw so they have title eight authority.

So bring some of them over to do this operation, we have to do it. It worked for me in FY15, Lou, the consequence deterrence works, we need to have it. We need to have it. It needs to be large-scale not a little bit here, a lot of bit there across the country.

DOBBS: Well, let me -- let me return to the -- to my question, why isn't it happening? The president wants it to happen. Cuccinelli, Morgan, they wanted to happen. What's the reason it's not happening?

HOMAN: I do not know. I mean, when I was ICE director I just did it. I didn't look for approval from the department, I didn't look for the approval of the White House, I did my job. There's 7,000 deportation officers in ICE, deportation officers.

DOBBS: Right.

HOMAN: Their job is to execute --

DOBBS: What are they doing right now, just out of curiosity? 7,000 people filling jobs that by the way, I know full well, that just isn't happening. So what are they doing?

HOMAN: Well, I know they're working hard, Lou. You know, they got -A- they got over 4,000 jails that you respond to the restless criminals before they hit -- they hit the streets for sanctuary cities.

We've lost that efficiency in the jail so to release the criminal alien. No one agent gets sit in account of jail Lou, and process 10 criminals in one shift. But when that sanctuary jail releases them, now whole team needs to go out into the community and find that criminal alien. So sanctuary cities that really hurt the efficiency of ICE operations.

DOBBS: All right, Tom Homan, always good to have you with us. We appreciate it, thank you.

HOMAN: Good to see you, sir.

DOBBS: President Trump taking the stage at U.S. Bank Arena in CincinnatiOhio among a number of other things. There he is, waving to the crowd. Again, over a hundred thousand people looking for tickets in the U.S. Bank Arena. There are only 18,000 seats available. I have been told reliably that the president has never talked to a group, a rally in which there was a vacant seat, can you imagine?

We expect President Trump to be taking up the 2020 radical Dem presidential hopefuls and his assessment of their two nights of debates and the disastrous Fed debacle of yesterday and what it means for the economy, for the American consumer and family. And we'll be talking about -- he will be talking about certainly his announcement of 10 percent tariffs on an additional $300 billion of Chinese goods and exports to this country.

The supporters by the way started lining up early this morning and by early, I mean, before 06:00 in the morning outside the arena of the president's trip to Ohio highlighting his plan to win the state again in 2020. You'll remember in 2016, he won Ohio by eight points over Hillary Clinton. The victory surprising many including that state's former governor, the (INAUDIBLE) irascible and never Trumper, John Kasich. Where's John Kasich these days? I want to find out.

What is unsurprising of course is the success that Ohioans are enjoying since the president took office and Cincinnati alone, the unemployment rate recently hit an 18-year low. And we'll have the president as he begins his address right after this quick handshake and this break. Stay with us.

DOBBS: Well, there is President Trump addressing his supporters at the U.S. Bank Arena in CincinnatiOhio, let's listen it.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: Trump banners and Trump hats and Trump buttons that I've never seen. True.

And this great congressman said, I don't know, sir, but I can tell you one thing, if the rest of the country is voting like Tennessee is voting, you're going to win by a lot and we won and we won by a lot -- we won by a lot.

Our nation is stronger today than ever before. We have the number one economy on earth, no economy is social.

We're rebuilding the awesome might of the United States military and soon it will be stronger relatively speaking than at any time in our history, and when we took over it was depleted. We took over a depleted military. It's not depleted anymore, I can tell you that.

Our spirit is strong, our stride is back and our stand is clear. We are finally putting America first, it's about time.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

DOBBS: Joining me now Tammy Bruce and Todd Starnes. Washington Times columnist Tammy Bruce as well as Fox Business contributor conservative columnist and best-selling author of the Culture Jihad right here. The book to be out quickly and we recommend it to you highly.

The president talking about all that has been achieved. It isn't as they say brag, it's fact.

TAMMY BRUCE, FOX BUSINESS CONTRIBUTOR: Yes, this -- it's remarkable, the president --

DOBBS: It is brag and a fact.

BRUCE: And he's -- and he's allowed to do so. It's been hard work considering what he's faced.

Last night we saw a bunch of Democrats who are being one way and we know that they're going to try to shift during a general election. Donald Trump showed everyone what Americans want. He's been himself from the start from coming down that golden escalator to tonight. Every day he's the same guy. He's made promises, he talked about issues and policies, he went into the office, he didn't change, he didn't have to adjust himself for the general election and he has been delivering.

This is the potential of the American presidency. It is the nature of the kinds of people that America delivers and raises and it's an exciting time.

DOBBS: What he's delivered Todd is also record low unemployment and that's what he's talking about right now in Cincinnati where they've benefited immensely from their decision to give an eight percent margin to the man who ultimately became president in 2016.

TODD STARNES, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CONTRIBUTOR: Lou, I come from a blue- collar family and I understand that at the end of the day, there are Republicans certainly Democrats who just don't really care about those kinds of workers, but President Trump does.

One of the things that I really appreciate about this president is the fact that he's stood up for those people who don't necessarily want to go to college. They want to be the construction workers, they want to be the mechanics. These are people who are taking on good and noble jobs and this president is affirming them. And that's one of the things I write about in this book is that this president is protecting the backbone of the -- of the country.

DOBBS: Let's listen to the president and catch up with where he is.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: No more left wing extremist to reject everything that we hold dear. No one has paid a higher price for the far-left destructive agenda than Americans living in our nation's inner cities, they have paid a dear price, you see what's happening. You see our inner cities. We spend billions and billions and billions for years and years and years and it's stolen money and it's wasted money and it's a shame.

For decades these communities have been run exclusively by Democrat politicians and it's been total one party control of the inner cities. For a hundred years has been one-party control and look at them, we can name one after another but I won't do that, because I don't want to be controversial. We want no controversy.

The Democrat record is one of neglect and corruption and decay, total decay. The Democrats have taxed and regulated jobs and opportunity out of these cities and out of existence, they've squeezed the blood out of them. Left-wing mayors and city --

(END VIDEO CLIP)

DOBBS: Concerns, the president doesn't want to be controversial and he is actually -- he is being ironic here. But at the same time, following that suggestion that he is somewhat constrained but getting his point across. He's not backing off about Baltimore. He's not backing off about the --

STARNES: That's right.

DOBBS: -- failed leadership in dozens of American cities, failed Democratic leadership and the need for them to make a change.

STARNES: You know, I wrote about this in my column on foxnews.com Lou, that at the end of the day, you have these cities, Los Angeles, where they're dealing with disease that goes back to the Middle Ages. You have San Francisco that has been turned into a cesspool of human waste. And now of course Baltimore, more than 50 years the Democrats have controlled, more than 50 years Democrats have controlled Baltimore.

DOBBS: Right.

STARNES: And what does it resulted in? It's a third world -- it's a third world situation.

DOBBS: Well, the president is taking up immigration here. Let's catch up with it.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: 21,000 soldiers on the border right now. I'm starting to like Mexico a lot. They do a lot more for us than the Democrats do, right? And the numbers are way down, you'll see that, way, way down. Democrat lawmakers care more about illegal aliens, than they care about their own constituents. They put foreign citizens before American citizens. We're not going to do that. 572 people were murdered in Chicago last year.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

DOBBS: That was one of the money lines when he talks about Democrats doing more for Americans -- I mean, the Mexican government doing more for Americans than Democrats.

BRUCE: Yes.

DOBBS: Stunning stuff, and it's --

BRUCE: Well, it's true.

DOBBS: And it's -- by the way, it's true right now. It's true.

BRUCE: See, that's it. This is a man who did not get the memo or refused to take the memo that forbids you from talking about the failed Democratic policies. Because that when he says that they don't care about their own constituency or their own base, look at Baltimore, and Chicago, and Los Angeles, and San Francisco, and Denver now, these cities, Detroit, etcetera. You've got people --

DOBBS: Let me interrupted just very quickly. The President is waiting. Apparently, there is a demonstrator in the crowd and they are chanting their way through this and the president taking it in stride, or pacing, depending on how you want to construct it. Go ahead, Tammy.

BRUCE: So that's, of course, what they've been reduced to, it's just yelling at him. In the meantime, he's changing everyone's lives for the better. But this is now -- finally, we have a president who is telling the political establishment and the media establishment, that no talking about the destruction of the inner city is the problem, not talking about how these individuals lives are more and more hopeless because of liberal policies.

The racism is in allowing that to continue. And in looking away, he doesn't look away. And that, of course, is part of his crime. The Democrats don't like that but this is also part of what he represents, the Forgotten man and woman. If there was ever forgotten man and woman, it's the people in Baltimore and the people in Chicago, people of New York and Los Angeles.

DOBBS: The President today speaking earlier -- let's listen in to that as we wait for the protester to, to perhaps exit the arena.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: The rage-filled Democratic Party is trying to tear America apart. The Democrat Party is now being led by four left-wing extremists to reject everything that we hold dear. No one is paid a higher price for the far left destructive agenda that Americans living in our nation's inner cities, they have paid a dear price. You see what's happening.

You see our inner cities. We spend billions and billions and billions for years and years and years. And it's stolen money, and it's wasted money. And it's a shame.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

DOBBS: And last year, it was $16 billion from the federal government for Baltimore. And Todd, this is -- this is failed leadership. It is empirical. It is absolutely in the face of everyone to look at this, what has happened to once a once-great city, Baltimore, but it's also happening in cities all across the country.

STARNES: Well, it certainly is. My hometown, Memphis, Tennessee, suffering the same fate as many of these other communities. And what is the common denominator? Memphis, Tennessee is run by Democrats. And we've been hearing from a lot of the residents of these communities who say they appreciate President Trump calling all of this out and shining a light on something that needs to be discussed.

DOBBS: You know, it's -- to me, it's stunning, Tam, that we have to have a light on this that the President had to focus on this. We've had a war on poverty in this country for the past 54 years, a half-century.

BRUCE: You know --

DOBBS: And we have cities like Baltimore in devastating.

BRUCE: You know, and that tells you something does, it's a little concerning to have to think about it, but maybe that was just a distraction. How much money has been spent on the war on poverty while everybody was looking away and not discussing its inherent failure perhaps? That's --

DOBBS: Well, not everybody is looking away. Let's be very clear. It is the leftist national media that has refused to look at what is before them --

BRUCE: Correct.

DOBBS: -- and to support a false narrative or the President puts it, fake news. Let's listen to the president here for a minute.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

TRUMP: It broke the all-time record. The homicide rate in Baltimore is significantly higher than El Salvador, Honduras, Guatemala. I believe it's higher than give me a -- give me a place that you think is pretty bad. Give me a place. The guy says Afghanistan, I believe it's higher than Afghanistan. In our country, think of that.

I believe -- we'll check the numbers and if we're wrong, they will tell us tomorrow. It'll be headlines. Trump exaggerated. I do believe the rate is higher than Afghanistan. Yet democrats and they've run it for many years want to spend hundreds of billions of dollars on illegal migrants instead of supporting their own struggling communities. No good. No good.

The conditions and Nancy Pelosi's once-great city of San Francisco are deplorable. They are deplorable. To remember the word deplorable, you remember when Hillary used the word deplorable? She used two words. She used deplorable and irredeemable, right?

And only being a politician for a few years. I said, what a terrible mistake that she used the word irredeemable. But it turned out to be deplorable. Deplorable was not a good day for Hillary. Crooked Hillary, she is a crooked one. She is crooked.

AMERICAN CROWD: Lock her up! Lock her up! Lock her up!

TRUMP: Nearly half of all the homeless people living in the streets in America happened to live in the state of California. What they are doing to our beautiful California is a disgrace to our country. It's a shame. The world is looking at it. Look at Los Angeles with the tents and the horrible, horrible, disgusting conditions.

Look at San Francisco, look at some of your other cities. And then you have a governor, you have a governor, that invites the whole world to come into California, we'll pay for your health care, we'll pay for it. And then you wonder why so many people are coming up.

They're coming up, because we're the hottest economic country in the world, but they're also coming up because you have people like that Governor, say come on up, we'll give you a healthcare. Come on. Who wouldn't come up? Who wouldn't come up? How crazy is this? How crazy is this, schools healthcare.

Today I have a simple proposal for Democrat leaders to support legislation to end illegal migration. And we will use the vast savings to rebuild our inner cities. That's the way we should be doing. That's the way we should be doing.

And by the way, you know, they keep talking about oh, the voters, the voters, the voters, they want all sorts of security. What about a thing called voter I.D., voter identification?

(END VIDEOTAPE)

DOBBS: By the way, for a fact-checkers among you. Let me tell you, my fact-checkers in the control room tell me that Afghanistan murders six per 100,000. In Baltimore, 56 -- wow -- per 100,000. Back to the President.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: Voter I.D. They give you everything they can give you except like voter I.D. and the things that matter. Republicans believe that a nation was care for its own citizens first. Our pledge to America's workers has secured commitments to train more than 12 million Americans for the jobs of tomorrow.

You know, he's working very hard on that? You probably never heard of her, Ivanka Trump. She's working very hard. She gave up a lot. She had a very easy life but she loves doing it. She's got over I think now 12 million people. They're teaching them, the great companies of our country, they're teaching people how to do it and it's an incredible thing to watch.

To give former prisoners a second chance at life, we pass groundbreaking criminal justice reform that nobody could have passed except us. President Obama tried, a lot of them tried, they couldn't get it passed. I got it passed with a lot of help from liberals and conservatives and a lot of help. And the biggest beneficiary is the African American community, biggest beneficiary.

And something which a lot of people don't talk about, but we doubled the child tax credit, doubled it. And our tax plan also created nearly 9,000 opportunity zones, hottest thing going providing massive new incentives for investment in job creation in distressed communities. Are you OK. Take your time. Take your time. Doctor, doctor in the house please.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

DOBBS: Someone apparently having a medical issue and the President calling for medical attention, a doctor. It is -- it is a stunning performance by this president to focus on all that is happening in this country. And I think amongst the developments of the day will be the joining of Chuck Schumer, in alignment with the president against China.

And by the way, the President aligned with the government of Mexico, this fellow can't be too much of "racist" in point of fact, bracing Mexico, its president, its government, because of all of the help their providing America, acknowledging it and doing so warmly, Because this President's against illegality. He is for Law and Order for America, and sovereignty, and borders that matter. What do you think?

BRUCE: Well, you know, what's interesting is, especially with Schumer's action, is that after the debates, we see this pulling away from the values of the American people, maybe his reaction is that maybe they need to find some kind of common ground with the president, because that's where America is. I think that's a good combination there.

DOBBS: I think the President is leading us -- we couldn't -- we couldn't ask a leader to do more than what this President is doing now to bring people together in point of fact.

STARNES: Well, you're absolutely right, Lou. And I suspect that the Democrats are looking at their numbers, and they're seeing that this President is making inroads into minority communities. And black voters are beginning to understand that this President truly does care about the plight of minorities and does care about these inner-city areas. He wants to get jobs back into those communities, and he wants to do something about education.

And again, the President is shining a very bright light on this. I think it terrifies to these Democrats because they know, they know that they have abandoned these communities.

DOBBS: The reality is that this President has always asserted a leadership that was not Republican in point of fact. He is not a conservative in the traditional sense. But he is an American in a very strong, traditional sense of keenly supportive and protective of our heritage, our values, indeed our nation and what it means to be an American.

There is an opportunity here for the Democrats, whether any of the 24 candidates who would like to oppose them in 2020 will embrace the opportunity. They might consider what happens is we watch as a result of Chuck Schumer lining up with the President on the issue of China. Tammy Bruce, Todd Starnes, thank you both. We thank you for being with us through this hour. We'll see you tomorrow night. Good night from New York.

urn:contentItem:5WMS-JW11-F11P-X48K-00000-00Comic: Antitrust and Regulatory Fears Set To Dominate Big Tech Earnings2019-07-23T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:35:22ZLexisNexisComic: Antitrust and Regulatory Fears Set To Dominate Big Tech Earnings

Investing.com -

By Jesse Cohen

Investing.com - The U.S. second-quarter earnings season shifts into high gear this week, with more than a quarter of the S&P 500 companies set to report their latest results in the coming days.

While blue chips like Boeing (NYSE:BA), McDonald's (NYSE:MCD), and United Technologies (NYSE:UTX) are among the more than 130 companies reporting, most of the focus will fall on tech heavyweights such as Facebook (NASDAQ:FB), Amazon (NASDAQ:AMZN), and Google-parent Alphabet (NASDAQ:GOOGL).

The three FANG names have been under scrutiny lately amid all the talk of antitrust charges, government regulation and cryptocurrency plans.

Facebook (NASDAQ:FB), which has surged 54% this year, is set to report its latest results after Wednesday's closing bell. The social media company is expected by analysts to post a profit of $1.87 per share on sales of about $16.5 billion, according to forecasts compiled by Investing.com.

Amazon (NASDAQ:AMZN) meanwhile is set to release its latest results on Thursday after the closing bell. The retail giant, which has seen shares gain 32% this year, is expected to earn $5.56 per share on revenue of $62.47 billion.

Joining Amazon (NASDAQ:AMZN) in report earnings after Thursday's closing bell will be Google-parent Alphabet (NASDAQ:GOOGL), which is projected to report earnings per share of $11.10. according to forecasts compiled by Investing.com. Revenue is forecast to total $38.16 billion. Shares are up just 9% this year.

The Trump administration's trifecta of antitrust investigations of Silicon Valley tech giants triggered a mass selloff of FANG stocks in early June.

Facebook got hammered amid revelations that the Federal Trade Commission launched an antitrust probe to determine if it engages in monopolistic practices, while Google dropped after news broke that the U.S. Justice Department is preparing an antitrust investigation of it.

Amazon is the other tech giant under scrutiny, which could face a broad FTC probe as well as heightened pressure from Europe.

To see more of Investing.com's weekly comics, visit: http://www.investing.com/analysis/comics

Cambió el viento. La interpelación del Congreso a las firmas tecnológicas indica que el sector tecnológico no podrá más hacer lo que quiere. Ayer los individuos más influyentes del planeta – Jim Cook de Apple, Sundar Pichai de Alphabet/Google y Mark Zucker...

Cambió el viento. La interpelación del Congreso a las firmas tecnológicas indica que el sector tecnológico no podrá más hacer lo que quiere. Ayer los individuos más influyentes del planeta – Jim Cook de Apple, Sundar Pichai de Alphabet/Google y Mark Zuckerberg de Facebook testificaron ante la Subcomisión Judiciaria Antimonopólica de la Casa de Representantes. La audiencia se concentró – aparte de algunas distracciones políticas – en temas antimonopólicos y política de competencia. Cada CEO defendió los productos y prácticas de su compañía, subrayando los beneficios para los consumidores y la competencia que sufren de otras firmas.- Pero fue evidente que a muchos legisladores no les convencieron pos las justificaciones. El presidente de la Subcomisión, David Cicilline, acusó a los cuatro de aplastar competidores e implementar prácticas desleales. Dijo que son “emperadores de la economía online” y pidió más controles y más regulación . agregó que “el poder económico concentrado” también conduce al “poder político concentrado”. Para concluir preguntando si “debemos permitir que nos gobiernen monopolios privados”. Los republicanos compartieron partes de la crítica tecnológica pero se concentraron más en la censura de los puntos de vista conservadores y las preocupaciones sobre prejuicios políticos. Jim Jordan dijo que “ Big Tech sale a cazar conservadores”. Le exigió a Pichai la promesa pública de que Google no va a diseñar productos y prácticas que beneficien a Joe Biden en la campaña presidencial de 2020. Sobre la base de esta audiencia y de los cambios en el sentimiento de la gente, Darrell West de la Brookings Institution cree que es probable que de ahora en más se abra una nueva era tecnológica con mayor control del público y mayor alcance regulatorio y medidas con más capacidad para hacer cumplir las directivas al sector tecnológico. Si los demócratas recuperan la presidencia, dice, y controlan el Senado, 2021 será un año en que la legislación nacional podría orientarse hacia temas como privacidad, competencia, cíber-seguridad y política fiscal., reforma de la Sección 230 y lenguaje de odio en Internet. Por eso las discusiones legislativas de esta semana son ilustrativas del marco político y regulatorio que gobernará la futura innovación tecnológica.
